docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
Formula: \(ECV = (1 - Hct) \times \frac{\Delta R1_{myo}}{\Delta R1_{blood}}\) where \(\Delta R1 = \frac{1}{T1_{post}} - \frac{1}{T1_{pre}}\)

ECV (%) Interpretation Clinical Context <30 Normal Normal extracellular matrix 30–32 Borderline Correlate with clinical context 32–40 Elevated Diffuse fibrosis / edema >40 Markedly Elevated Consider amyloid or severe fibrosis

Measurement Tips

  • Use the same 3 slices (base/mid/apex) for pre- and post-contrast MOLLI — identical slice positions matter
  • Blood pool T1 measured from a ROI in the LV cavity (avoid trabeculae)
  • Gadolinium should fully equilibrate before post-Gd MOLLI — ideally ≥10 min post-injection
  • Hematocrit from same-day labs; point-of-care Hct is acceptable
  • At 1.5T: native T1 ~950–1050 ms (myo), ~1600–1750 ms (blood); at 3T: ~1150–1300 ms (myo), ~1800–2000 ms (blood)

docs.title: Cardiac CT
docs.text: Scanning protocols for cardiac CT are maintained in the Radiology Protocol Manager. This page covers reporting pearls and key measurements used during interpretation.

docs.title: CAD-RADS 2.0 Reporting
docs.text:
CAD-RADS Stenosis Recommendation 0 No stenosis No CAD 1 1–24% Minimal, non-obstructive 2 25–49% Mild, non-obstructive 3 50–69% Moderate — functional testing recommended 4A 70–99% (1–2 vessels) Severe — ICA or FFR-CT 4B 70–99% (LM or 3-vessel) Severe — heart team 5 Total occlusion N Non-diagnostic segment

Modifiers: +HRP (high-risk plaque), +S (stent), +G (graft), +E (exception), +I (ischemia)

High-Risk Plaque Features

Low attenuation plaque (<30 HU), positive remodeling (RI >1.1), napkin-ring sign, spotty calcification

docs.title: TMVR / TTVR Planning CT
docs.text:
• Mitral annulus: D-shaped, measure perimeter and area in systole (perpendicular to LVOT)
  • Neo-LVOT: Model potential LVOT obstruction — critical if <170–190 mm²
  • Interatrial septum: Thickness and trajectory for transseptal approach
  • Tricuspid annulus: Saddle-shaped; measure in systole; note associated RV dilation

docs.title: LAAO Planning CT
docs.text:
Key Measurements

  • LAA ostium: Max and min diameter + area (elliptical shape) — guides device size (+3–5 mm)
  • LAA landing zone: 1–2 cm from ostium; measure max/min diameter
  • LAA morphology: Chicken wing, cactus, windsock, cauliflower (↑ stroke risk)
  • Thrombus: Residual enhancement on delayed phase (60 s) excludes thrombus

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Cardiac Anesthesia

  • 4 cardiac issues that will make anesthetists stressed if you ask them to do a study under GA:
  • Severe aortic stenosis
  • Pulmonary Hypertension
  • Severe LV heart failure
  • Arrhythmia (ventricular)

Motion Artifacts (ghosting)

  • Arrhythmia: switch to real-time cine (lower resolution but no ECG issues)
  • Breathing: use free-breathing with navigator; check patient coaching
  • Cine ghosting: check VENC if using velocity-encoded sequence; check shimming

LGE — Wrong TI

Always run a TI scout after gadolinium dosing. Re-run if myocardium not nulled (appears bright on PSIR inversion images).

Banding Artifacts (bSSFP)

Banding from B₀ inhomogeneity: re-shim, or switch to 1.5T equivalent (spoiled GRE / FIESTA at off-resonance range). More problematic at 3T.

4D Flow Quality Check

  • Velocity aliasing: increase VENC (but SNR decreases)
  • Flow inconsistencies: SVC + IVC should ≈ PA; Ao ≈ PA in normal hearts
  • Check background phase correction in post-processing software

docs.title: Contrast Doses
docs.text:
Use Dose Agent Standard LGE / perfusion 0.1 mmol/kg (single) Gadolinium-based (macrocyclic preferred) Perfusion + LGE same study 0.1 mmol/kg for perfusion; additional 0.05–0.1 for LGE if needed — T1 mapping (ECV) 0.1 mmol/kg Record pre-contrast T1 first

NSF Risk

Use macrocyclic agents (Group II) for patients with eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m². Avoid linear agents. Discuss risk/benefit if eGFR <15 or on dialysis.

docs.title: Cardiac Function Protocol
docs.text: Indications: Cardiomyopathy evaluation, pre/post-chemotherapy, valve disease follow-up, congenital disease, RV assessment, pre-operative evaluation.

docs.title: Sequence Order
docs.text: # Sequence View Notes 1 Localizers 3-plane Quick survey 2 Dark blood HASTE Axial stack (thorax) Morphology survey; pericardium; pleura 3 Cine SSFP 4CH LV/RV function, mitral + tricuspid 4 Cine SSFP 2CH LV function, mitral 5 Cine SSFP 3CH (LVOT) LVOTO assessment, aortic valve 6 Cine SSFP SAX stack (base → apex in 8 mm steps) Volumetry — primary EF / EDV / ESV measurement 7 Cine SSFP RVOT Pulmonic valve, RVOT morphology 8 Cine SSFP Aortic valve (en face) Valve morphology, orifice 9 T2 mapping 3 SAX (base/mid/apex) Optional — if edema suspected

docs.title: Key Measurements to Report
docs.text:
• LV: EDV, ESV, SV, EF, mass (indexed to BSA)
  • RV: EDV, ESV, SV, EF (right-heart dedicated SAX or axial stack)
  • Wall motion: Segmental (17-segment AHA model) — describe hypokinesis, akinesis, dyskinesis
  • Pericardium: Effusion volume, thickening, calcification
  • Valves: Qualitative assessment of regurgitation on cine

SAX Volumetry Tips

  • Include basal slices that show >50% myocardium in the plane
  • Contour from first slice with clear septal muscle (not AV plane) to apex
  • RVOT can be tricky — sometimes exclude if partially through tricuspid plane

docs.title: Congenital / 4D Flow Protocol
docs.text: Indications: Congenital heart disease (ASD, VSD, TOF, TGA, Fontan, coarctation), shunt quantification, valvular flow (AR/PR from CMR), vessel stenosis assessment.

docs.title: Sequence Order
docs.text:
# Sequence View Notes 1 Localizers 3-plane 2 Dark blood HASTE Axial stack (thorax) Situs, connections, great vessel relationships 3 Dark blood HASTE Coronal / oblique sagittal Aortic arch, PA, SVC/IVC anatomy 4 Cine SSFP 4CH, 2CH, 3CH LV/RV function; AV valve regurgitation 5 Cine SSFP SAX stack (LV) LV volumetry and wall motion 6 Cine SSFP SAX stack (RV-focused if needed) RV volumetry; free wall 7 Cine SSFP RVOT, LVOT, aortic arch, PA bifurcation Site-specific cines for stenosis and morphology 8 2D Phase Contrast Perpendicular to Ao, PA, LPA, RPA Flow quantification; Qp:Qs 9 4D Flow Volume covering heart and great vessels Replaces 2D PC if available; post-process for all vessels 10 LGE (if Gd given) SAX + LAX RV insertion points; fibrosis in systemic RV

2D PC vs. 4D Flow

2D PC is faster and works well when you know the specific vessels to measure. 4D flow allows retrospective plane placement and WSS/visualization — better for complex anatomy or when vessels are uncertain.

docs.title: Phase Contrast (2D PC) — Practical Tips
docs.text:
• VENC: Set 10–20% above expected peak velocity. Aliasing artifacts = increase VENC. Too high VENC = poor SNR.
  • Typical: Ao ~150–180 cm/s, PA ~100–130 cm/s, SVC ~60–80 cm/s
  • Plane placement: Perpendicular to vessel long axis; avoid turbulence zones (place 1–2 cm from valve)
  • Background phase correction: Apply in post-processing if available (e.g., use stationary tissue outside vessel)

docs.title: Qp:Qs Calculation
docs.text:
Standard: \(\frac{Qp}{Qs} = \frac{\text{PA net flow}}{\text{Ao net flow}}\)

If LPA + RPA measured: use sum as Qp.

Use the 4D Flow Calculator on the Calculators page.

docs.title: Regurgitant Fraction
docs.text:
\(RF = \frac{\text{Backward flow}}{\text{Forward flow}} \times 100\%\)

RF Severity <20% Trivial/Mild 20–39% Moderate ≥40% Severe

docs.title: Key Reporting Elements
docs.text:
• Situs and connections: Situs (solitus/inversus/ambiguous), visceroatrial concordance, AV and ventriculoarterial concordance
  • Shunts: Qp:Qs, shunt direction, size of defect on cine
  • Biventricular function: EDVi, EF for both ventricles (BSA-indexed)
  • Flow measurements: Net flows (mL/beat) for Ao, PA, LPA, RPA; RF for pulmonary regurgitation
  • Stenosis: Gradient by modified Bernoulli from peak PC velocity
  • LPA:RPA ratio: Normal ~55:45; >60:40 = asymmetric flow (branch PA stenosis)
  • Collateral flow (Fontan): Qp − Fontan flow; >20% suggests significant aortopulmonary collaterals

docs.title: Stress Perfusion Protocol
docs.text:
Indications: Known or suspected CAD, ischemia evaluation (alternative to nuclear), pre/post revascularization assessment.

Stress agents: Adenosine (140 mcg/kg/min × 4–6 min), Regadenoson (0.4 mg bolus), Dobutamine (10–40 mcg/kg/min — for bSSFP cine stress wall motion if vasodilator contraindicated)

docs.title: Contraindications to Vasodilator Stress
docs.text:
Contraindications

  • Active bronchospasm / severe asthma
  • High-degree AV block (2° or 3°) without pacemaker
  • Systolic BP <90 mmHg
  • Dipyridamole within 24 h (potentiates adenosine)
  • Caffeine within 12 h (blocks adenosine receptors — hold coffee day of scan)

docs.title: Sequence Order
docs.text:
# Sequence View Notes 1 Localizers 3-plane 2 Dark blood HASTE Axial Morphology 3 Cine SSFP 4CH, 2CH, 3CH, RVOT, SAX Baseline function / wall motion 4 Rest Perfusion 3 SAX (base/mid/apex) + 4CH 0.075–0.1 mmol/kg Gd bolus at ~2 mL/s 5 Rest cines (repeat if wall motion question) SAX Optional 6 — Begin stress agent infusion Allow 2–4 min before stress imaging 7 Stress Perfusion Same 3 SAX slices At peak stress; same contrast dose 8 Wait 10–15 min — Gadolinium equilibrates 9 TI Scout Mid-SA 10 LGE SAX stack + LAX Scar assessment

Contrast Dose

Use half-dose (0.05–0.075 mmol/kg) per perfusion acquisition to avoid T2* saturation artifact. Some protocols use full dose (0.1) — be consistent with your institution.

docs.title: Normal vs. Abnormal
docs.text:
• Normal: Uniform signal uptake in myocardium following gadolinium bolus. LV myocardium brightens uniformly from endo to epi.
  • Perfusion defect: Subendocardial or transmural dark region on first-pass images, corresponding to territory of stenosed vessel.
  • Dark rim artifact: Thin (1 pixel) subendocardial dark rim — common, especially at base. Not a true defect if limited to 1 slice and no corresponding LGE.

docs.title: Viability Protocol
docs.text: Indications: Ischemic cardiomyopathy (scar quantification for revascularization decision), non-ischemic cardiomyopathy characterization (HCM, DCM, myocarditis, infiltrative), ECV calculation.

docs.title: LGE Patterns and Diagnosis
docs.text:
Pattern Distribution Likely Diagnosis Subendocardial / transmural Coronary territory Ischemic scar Mid-wall Septal (IVS) "stripe" DCM, myocarditis, LBBB Subepicardial Lateral wall Myocarditis (focal) Diffuse subendocardial Global, circumferential Amyloid; also consider ECV RV insertion points Bilateral septal junctions Pressure overload (pulm HTN, TOF) Patchy / geographic HCM segments HCM — correlates with arrhythmia risk Pericardium Delayed enhancement Pericarditis

Ischemic vs. Non-Ischemic

Ischemic scar always starts at the endocardium and may extend transmurally. Non-ischemic patterns (mid-wall, subepicardial, RV insertion) are never endocardial-dominant.

docs.title: Transmural Extent and Viability
docs.text: Transmural Extent Likelihood of Functional Recovery with Revascularization 0% (no LGE) High 1–25% High 26–50% Intermediate 51–75% Unlikely >75% Very unlikely

docs.title: ECV Calculation
docs.text:
Formula: \(ECV = (1 - Hct) \times \frac{\Delta R1_{myo}}{\Delta R1_{blood}}\)

Where \(\Delta R1 = \frac{1}{T1_{post}} - \frac{1}{T1_{pre}}\) (in ms⁻¹)

Use the ECV Calculator on the Calculators page.

ECV (%) Interpretation <25 Normal 25–30 Borderline 30–40 Diffuse fibrosis / edema >40 Markedly elevated — amyloid?

Amyloid Pattern

High native T1, high ECV, diffuse subendocardial LGE, difficulty nulling myocardium, small LV with thick walls + preserved/reduced EF. RV involvement common.

docs.title: Congenital Heart Disease
docs.text:
CMR reporting template and reference for imaging pearls in common CHD entities.

Normal TOF TGA ccTGA DORV ASD VSD Fontan CoA Ebstein AVSD Segmental Analysis Template 📋 Copy Template

Situs: Situs solitus by normal spleen in the left upper quadrant and normal pulmonary arteries and airways relationships.

Cavae: Single right-sided SVC and single right-sided IVC drain to the right atrium unobstructed.

Pulmonary Veins: Two right-sided pulmonary vein(s) and Two left-sided pulmonary vein(s) drain to the left atrium. No evidence of compression, stenosis or anomalous pulmonary venous return.

Atria: No gross interatrial communication.

Atrioventricular Connection: Concordant. An endocardial cushion and two distinct atrioventricular valves are present.

Ventricles: D-loop with levocardia. Both ventricles are normal in size, morphology and function. No gross interventricular communication.

Ventriculoarterial Connection: Concordant. Main pulmonary artery courses anterior and to the left of the ascending aorta, consistent with normal position of the great arteries.

Coronary Arteries: Right and left coronary arteries originate from their expected sinuses of Valsalva.

Aorta: Left-sided aortic arch with normal branching pattern. No evidence of aneurysm, coarctation or major aorto-pulmonary collateral arteries.

Pulmonary Arteries: Central pulmonary arteries are patent. No evidence of dilatation or stenosis.

Miscellaneous: None.

docs.title: General MRI Tips
docs.text:
General Approach

  1. Morphology first — dark blood (HASTE/TSE) axial stack for situs, connections, great vessel relationships
  2. Cine function — SAX stack of each ventricle (measure volumes separately)
  3. Flow — 2D PC or 4D flow at Ao, PA, LPA, RPA, any shunt vessel
  4. LGE — assess fibrosis, especially in systemic RV patients
  5. T1/T2 mapping — if myocarditis, infiltrative, or congestive hepatopathy suspected

Breath-holding: Use free-breathing with respiratory navigator for uncooperative patients or complex anatomy requiring long sequences.

Sedation/anesthesia: Required for young children; coordinate with anesthesia for timing of sequences.

docs.title: Classification
docs.text: Type Prevalence Key Features Secundum 70% Central defect in fossa ovalis; most common Primum 15% Lower, involves AV valve tissue; part of AVSD spectrum Sinus venosus 10% Defect near SVC or IVC; often with anomalous PV return Coronary sinus 5% Rare; drain to coronary sinus

docs.title: Hemodynamic Significance
docs.text:
Shunt magnitude from 4D Flow: - Qp:Qs <1.5: Small defect, typically asymptomatic; closure not routinely indicated - Qp:Qs 1.5–2.0: Moderate; warrants monitoring - Qp:Qs >2.0: Large; generally indicated for closure to prevent RV dilation and late complications

Volume overload signs: - RV dilation - RA enlargement - LV compression (RV dilation in diastole)

docs.title: 4D Flow Assessment
docs.text:
• Qp:Qs calculation: Pulmonary artery net flow vs aortic net flow
  • Shunt location: 4D flow can visualize the actual defect and shunt vector
  • Anomalous pulmonary venous return: Especially in sinus venosus ASD (right upper PV commonly drains to SVC)

docs.title: Closure Consideration
docs.text:
Sizing for transcatheter closure: - TEE provides stretched balloon diameter (hemodynamic) - CT/CMR provides static anatomic measurements of rims and defect diameter - Adequate rims needed for device stability (usually >5 mm)

Surgical closure: If anatomy unsuitable for device (rims too short, multiple defects, or PV anomaly requiring surgical correction)

docs.title: Long-term Follow-up
docs.text: Post-closure assessment by echocardiography or cardiac CT to ensure device position and assess for residual shunting.

docs.title: Anatomy
docs.text:
Hallmark: Deficiency of the atrioventricular septum resulting in: - Primum atrial septal defect: Opening between atria - Inlet ventricular septal defect: Opening between ventricles - Common atrioventricular valve: Single valve tissue bridging both atria and ventricles

Associated features: - Left AV valve cleft: Separation between left superior and inferior bridging leaflets - Goose-neck deformity: Elongation and narrowing of left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) - Anterior aortic position: Relative to posteriorly positioned pulmonary artery

docs.title: Classification
docs.text: Type Features Partial AVSD (Ostium primum ASD) Primum ASD only; individual AV valves present; cleft in MV common Intermediate AVSD Small inlet VSD; common AV valve tissue above & below Complete AVSD Large primum ASD + inlet VSD; single common AV valve Rastelli types A (symmetric), B (asymmetric), C (asymmetric with displacement)

docs.title: Hemodynamics
docs.text:
Left-to-right shunting: - Atrial level (primum ASD) - Ventricular level (inlet VSD) - Magnitude depends on defect size and relative AV valve insufficiency

Associated pulmonary hypertension: - Common in complete AVSD if unrepaired - Contributes to progressive left AV valve regurgitation

docs.title: Morphology
docs.text:
• Defect extent: Dark blood imaging (HASTE/TSE) axial and coronal views delineate primum ASD and inlet VSD
  • Common AV valve assessment: Identify single vs cleft valve
  • LVOT narrowing: Sagittal views to assess goose-neck deformity and degree of left AV valve override

docs.title: Ventricular Function
docs.text:
• LV volume and EF: Secondary LV dilation from ASD and VSD
  • RV volume and EF: RV dilation from atrial-level shunting
  • Septation: Position of bridging leaflets at AV junction level

docs.title: AV Valve Regurgitation
docs.text:
• Left AV valve: Most commonly insufficient; quantify by 4D flow
  • Right AV valve: May have cleft; assess competence
  • Severity scoring: Mild, moderate, severe regurgitation

docs.title: Flow Assessment
docs.text:
• 4D flow: Quantify shunt magnitude (Qp:Qs)
  • Bidirectional flow at defects: If pulmonary hypertension present

docs.title: Associated Findings
docs.text:
• Down syndrome: Present in ~25% of patients with AVSD
  • Heterotaxy: Disorders of situs may coexist (laterality issues)
  • Other congenital lesions: TOF, hypoplastic left heart features may accompany

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Significant shunting: Qp:Qs >1.5 in partial AVSD, virtually all complete AVSD
  • Symptomatic patients: Poor growth, recurrent infections
  • Pulmonary hypertension prevention: Earlier repair if risk factors

docs.title: Technique
docs.text:
• Primary closure of primum ASD
  • Closure of inlet VSD
  • Reconstruction of cleft left AV valve
  • Maintain separate AV valve orifices

docs.title: Post-repair Complications
docs.text:
• Left AV valve regurgitation: May progress despite surgical repair
  • Can necessitate valve replacement later in life
  • Subaortic stenosis: Residual LVOT obstruction from goose-neck anatomy
  • Arrhythmias: Heart block risk (proximity to conduction tissue)
  • AV valve insufficiency recurrence: Valve leaflet degeneration

docs.title: Imaging Follow-up
docs.text: Serial CMR and/or echocardiography to monitor: - Ventricular volume and function - Residual shunting - Left AV valve regurgitation progression - LVOT obstruction (if present) - Arrhythmia development

docs.title: Congenitally Corrected Transposition of the Great Arteries (ccTGA)
Overview
docs.text: Congenitally corrected transposition (also called L-transposition or L-TGA) is characterized by discordant atrioventricular and discordant ventriculoarterial connections. Despite the abnormal morphology, the physiology is "corrected" at rest because systemic venous return ultimately reaches the lungs, and pulmonary venous return reaches the systemic circulation—however, the systemic right ventricle is at increased risk for ventricular dysfunction over time.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Concordance paradox: Two levels of discordance ("double discordance") result in concordant physiology
  • L-loop ventricles: Left-sided morphologic left ventricle (subpulmonary), right-sided morphologic right ventricle (systemic)
  • Levocardia (normally positioned heart) with inverted chambering
  • Associated lesions very common: VSD, left AV valve regurgitation (systemic mitral valve), Ebstein-like tricuspid deformity, subaortic stenosis, conduction abnormalities

docs.title: Situs and Orientation
docs.text:
• Usually situs solitus but heterotaxy is common
  • Levocardia with normal cardiac position despite inverted chamber arrangement
  • May be associated with other situs abnormalities—evaluate carefully

docs.title: Venous Drainage
docs.text:
• Systemic venous return (SVC + IVC) drains to morphologic left atrium (on right side)
  • Pulmonary venous return drains to morphologic right atrium (on left side)
  • Anomalous pulmonary venous return is frequently associated—check all four pulmonary veins

docs.title: Atrioventricular Connections (Discordant)
docs.text:
• Morphologic right atrium → mitral valve → morphologic left ventricle (subpulmonary, in left position)
  • Morphologic left atrium → tricuspid valve → morphologic right ventricle (systemic, in right position)
  • Systemic mitral valve regurgitation is common (acts as systemic AV valve)
  • Tricuspid valve abnormalities: Ebstein-like malposition with apical displacement and dysplasia

docs.title: Ventricles
docs.text:
• Morphologic left ventricle (subpulmonary):
  • Small, compact morphology
  • In left position (appears as "RV" on echocardiography)

  • Gives rise to pulmonary artery

  • Morphologic right ventricle (systemic):

  • Dilated, thin-walled, less compliant
  • In right position (appears as "LV" on echocardiography)
  • Supports systemic circulation

  • Progressive dilation and dysfunction common in adulthood

  • Ventricular septal defect: Present in ~70–80% of ccTGA cases

  • Usually perimembranous or subarterial
  • May partially restrict left-to-right blood flow

docs.title: Ventriculoarterial Connections (Discordant)
docs.text:
• Morphologic left ventricle (subpulmonary) → aorta (posteriorly positioned, arises from left-sided ventricle)
  • Morphologic right ventricle (systemic) → pulmonary artery (anteriorly positioned, arises from right-sided ventricle)
  • Great arteries typically anterior–posterior relationship or side-by-side

docs.title: Coronary Arteries
docs.text:
• Mirror-image coronary pattern is typical
  • Right coronary artery arises from left-facing sinus (anterior)
  • Left coronary system arises from right-facing sinus (posterior)
  • Coronary ostia may be higher or in abnormal positions
  • Critical for surgical planning (during potential future procedures)

docs.title: Aorta
docs.text:
• Arises from morphologic left ventricle (in subpulmonary position but giving rise to aorta)
  • Typically posterior and to the left relative to pulmonary artery
  • Monitor for:
  • Aortic root dilation
  • Aortic regurgitation (related to VSD anatomy or endocarditis risk)

docs.title: Pulmonary Arteries
docs.text:
• Branch pulmonary arteries usually patent and normally sized
  • May show reduced flow if severe subaortic stenosis (left ventricular outflow tract obstruction)

docs.title: Associated Lesions
docs.text: Lesion Frequency Clinical Significance VSD 70–80% Permits left-to-right shunt; position determines surgical approach Pulmonary stenosis 25–30% Variable; worsens systemic RV afterload Subaortic stenosis 10–20% LVOT obstruction; may require surgical relief Left AV valve regurgitation 40–50% Increases systemic RV volume load; progressive Tricuspid abnormality 10–30% Ebstein-like malposition; worsens TR Conduction abnormalities 50–80% Heart block common; may need pacing; CNS heterotaxy may have situs inversus totalis with right-sided IVC/SVC Heterotaxy/asplenia/polysplenia 5–10% Assess situs carefully

docs.title: Morphologic Assessment
docs.text:
1. Recognizing the inversion:
  2. Use systemic venous return to identify the morphologic left atrium (receives SVC + IVC)
  3. Morphologic ventricle identification: trabeculae, papillary muscles, valve attachments

  4. L-loop: Morphologic LV on left, morphologic RV on right (opposite of normal)

  5. Chamber size and function:

  6. Measure systemic RV volumes and ejection fraction (may be reduced)
  7. Estimate subpulmonary LV size (usually small)

  8. Quantify left (systemic mitral) and right AV valve regurgitation

  9. VSD localization:

  10. Careful cine imaging in multiple planes to define VSD type
  11. Position relative to great arteries (important for operative planning)

docs.title: Flow Imaging
docs.text:
• 4D flow or 2D PC through great arteries to assess:
  • Systemic-to-pulmonary shunt (if VSD present)
  • Systemic AV valve (mitral) regurgitation fraction
  • Subaortic obstruction gradient
  • Branch pulmonary artery flow balance

docs.title: LGE/Fibrosis Assessment
docs.text:
• Assess for myocardial replacement fibrosis in systemic RV (related to chronic volume/pressure overload)
  • Fibrosis correlates with ventricular dysfunction and arrhythmia risk

docs.title: Associated Anomalies
docs.text:
• Pulmonary and systemic venous return anatomy
  • Coronary artery origins and course (may require dedicated coronary CMR protocol)
  • Situs and other congenital associations

docs.title: Uncorrected (Native) ccTGA
docs.text:
• Presentation: Often cyanotic if VSD absent or restrictive; may be acyanotic if large VSD provides adequate mixing
  • Young adulthood: Systemic RV tolerates hemodynamic load reasonably well
  • Progressive dysfunction: 25–30-year-old patients often show declining RV function and increasing valve regurgitation
  • Complications: Arrhythmias, heart failure, endocarditis risk

docs.title: Post-Surgical (if prior intervention)
docs.text:
• VSD closure if hemodynamically significant
  • Pulmonary stenosis relief or RV outflow tract procedures
  • Double switch operation (rare, very young patients): Restores LV as systemic ventricle
  • Atrial switch + arterial switch (historical, less common now)

docs.title: Cardiac
docs.text:
• Conduction abnormalities: ~50% have heart block (related to abnormal AV nodal location)
  • Arrhythmias: Atrial flutter/fibrillation common in older patients; pre-excitation (WPW) possible
  • Endocarditis: Increased risk with VSD and valve abnormalities

docs.title: Extracardiac
docs.text:
• Heterotaxy: Assess splenic position, sidedness of vena cava, lung airway anatomy
  • Cardiac malposition (dextrocardia possible but rare in ccTGA)
  • Associated syndromes: Down syndrome (Trisomy 21)

docs.title: Natural History
docs.text:
• Infants and children often cyanotic; cyanosis may improve with growth or spontaneous closure of PDA
  • Adolescents and young adults generally stable if uncomplicated
  • Systemic RV dysfunction typically emerges in 3rd–4th decade
  • Survival to adulthood without intervention is possible but long-term outcome depends on degree of associated lesions

docs.title: Management Considerations
docs.text:
1. Asymptomatic uncomplicated ccTGA with large VSD:
  2. May not require early intervention

  3. Serial follow-up for RV size and function

  4. Restrictive VSD or cyanosis:

  5. Balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind) in infancy if inadequate mixing

  6. VSD closure if hemodynamically significant

  7. Progressive RV dysfunction, valve regurgitation:

  8. Afterload reduction therapy
  9. Consider double switch operation (controversial; best in young children)

  10. Heart transplantation if end-stage

  11. Endocarditis prophylaxis:

  12. Recommended for patients with VSD or valve abnormalities

docs.title: Key Teaching Points
docs.text: ✓ Two discordances = concordant physiology: Abnormal anatomy delivers blood appropriately but with systemic RV at risk ✓ Mirror-image coronaries: Right coronary from left sinus (anterior) — critical for surgery ✓ Systemic RV dysfunction: The limiting factor; emerges decades into life ✓ High association with VSD, valve regurgitation, subaortic stenosis, and conduction abnormalities ✓ Heterotaxy is frequent: Always assess situs and splenic position

docs.title: References & Further Reading
docs.text:
• Anderson RH, Baker EJ, Macartney FJ, et al. Paediatric cardiology. 3rd ed. Churchill Livingstone; 2010.
  • Fathallah A, Felfli M, Albabtain A. Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries: a review of imaging findings and management strategies. Insights Imaging. 2020;11(1):122.
  • Presbitero P, Saracino A, Somerville J. Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries. Am J Cardiol. 1995;76(3):153–157.

docs.title: Anatomy
docs.text:
Location: Narrowing of descending thoracic aorta, typically at the isthmus (just distal to left subclavian artery takeoff).

Classification: - Preductal: Proximal to ductus arteriosus (rare; associated with hypoplastic left heart features) - Juxtaductal: At the level of ductus arteriosus (most common) - Postductal: Distal to ductus arteriosus

docs.title: Hemodynamics
docs.text:
• Native anatomy: Narrowing causes proximal hypertension and reduced distal flow
  • Collateral development: Intercostal, internal mammary vessels enlarge to decompress proximal aorta (can be prominent on imaging)
  • Gradient: By PC velocity and Bernoulli equation
  • Note: PC likely underestimates true gradient if significant collateral decompression is present

docs.title: CMR Imaging
docs.text:
Morphology: - Axial dark blood imaging to visualize narrowing - Sagittal reconstructions to measure coarctation shelf - Note bicuspid aortic valve (present in ~50% of CoA)

Flow assessment: - PC velocity at narrowest point - Mild: <2 m/s - Moderate–severe: >2 m/s (Bernoulli: ΔP = 4V² = >16 mmHg) - Compare proximal (ascending aorta) vs distal (descending aorta) flow

Aortic root/ascending aorta: - Measure diameter at annulus, sinuses, sinotubular junction - Aortic root dilation common and progressive

docs.title: Associated Findings
docs.text:
• Bicuspid aortic valve: ~50% association; assess for stenosis or regurgitation
  • Hypoplastic features: Narrowed aortic arch, underdeveloped descending thoracic aorta
  • Turner syndrome: Increased CoA coexistence; screen for other cardiac/renal abnormalities
  • Mitral valve abnormalities: Hypoplastic MV
  • Ventricular septal defect: May coexist

docs.title: Surgical Repair (End-to-end anastomosis or patch)
docs.text:
• Re-coarctation: Narrowing at repair site; occurs in 10–20% over years
  • Aneurysm: Especially at Dacron patch sites; risk of rupture
  • Aortic root changes: Continued progression of dilation despite successful repair

docs.title: Balloon Expandable Stent Placement
docs.text:
• Effective for postoperative re-coarctation
  • Complications: Residual narrowing, aortic wall perforation, stent fracture

docs.title: Hypertension Management
docs.text:
• Pre-repair: Often severe hypertension; medications required
  • Post-repair: Hypertension may persist even after successful repair due to aortic stiffness
  • Long-term monitoring essential (home BP checks, antihypertensive therapy)

docs.title: Imaging Follow-up
docs.text: Serial imaging (CMR or CT) to assess: - Residual narrowing and peak velocity - Aortic root growth - Development of collaterals (if re-narrowing) - Associated lesion progression (e.g., aortic stenosis)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Double Outlet Right Ventricle (DORV) is a rare but complex lesion in which both the aorta and pulmonary artery arise predominantly or entirely from the morphologic right ventricle. The morphologic left ventricle contributes minimal or no blood to the great arteries. Communication between the right and left ventricles via a ventricular septal defect (VSD) is essential for survival, as it provides the only outlet for left ventricular blood.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Both great arteries originate from the RV: Usually >50% of each artery arises from the RV
  • Obligatory VSD: Systemic-to-pulmonary connection essential for survival
  • Variable anatomy: Great artery relationships (anterior–posterior, side-by-side, right-to-left) and VSD position vary widely
  • Associated lesions: Heterotaxy, pulmonary stenosis, hypoplastic pulmonary arteries, other CHD
  • Complex surgical anatomy: Repair strategy depends on VSD location relative to great arteries

docs.title: Situs and Orientation
docs.text:
• Usually situs solitus but heterotaxy is common (~30% of DORV patients)
  • Levocardia typical, but various cardiac positions possible
  • Evaluate splenic and visceral situs carefully

docs.title: Venous Drainage
docs.text:
• Systemic venous return (SVC + IVC) typically drains to right atrium (normal)
  • Pulmonary venous return typically drains to left atrium (normal)
  • Anomalous pulmonary venous return possible; assess all four PVs

docs.title: Atrioventricular Connections
docs.text:
• Concordant: Right atrium → tricuspid valve → morphologic right ventricle
  • Concordant: Left atrium → mitral valve → morphologic left ventricle
  • AV connections are normal; abnormality is entirely at ventriculoarterial level

docs.title: Ventricles
docs.text:
• Morphologic right ventricle (dominant chamber):
  • Enlarged, receives blood from both atria (via tricuspid valve) and from LV (via VSD)
  • Gives rise to both aorta and pulmonary artery

  • Hypertrophied walls

  • Morphologic left ventricle (hypoplastic, "unwedged"):

  • Small chamber, "wedged" between aortic root and ventricular septum
  • No outlet to great arteries (or minimal contribution)

  • Blood escapes via VSD to RV

  • Ventricular septal defect (obligatory):

  • Communication between RV and LV essential for pulmonary and systemic blood flow
  • VSD classification by position:
    • Subarterial (doubly committed): Directly under both PA and aorta
    • Perimembranous with RV outlet extension: Under both arteries but via membranous defect
    • Perimembranous with inlet extension: Rare, further from arteries
    • Remote VSD: Far from both great arteries; uncommon in DORV

docs.title: Ventriculoarterial Connections (Abnormal—Both from RV)
docs.text:
• Aorta arises from RV: Usually with variable degree of override from LV (typically >50% arises from RV)
  • Pulmonary artery arises from RV: Variable position and take-off relative to aorta
  • Relationship of great arteries:
  • Anterior–posterior: Aorta anterior to PA, or vice versa (most common)
  • Side-by-side: Aorta to the right of PA
  • PA appears to override VSD: Rare but possible (mimics PA-concordant physiology)

docs.title: Coronary Arteries
docs.text:
• Coronary ostia typically arise from expected sinuses despite abnormal great artery positions
  • May be displaced or abnormally positioned in ~10–15% of cases
  • Coronary assessment critical before surgical planning to avoid inadvertent injury during arterial transposition

docs.title: Aorta
docs.text:
• Arises predominantly from morphologic right ventricle
  • Position variable: anterior, posterior, or side-by-side relative to pulmonary artery
  • Systemic output dependent on RV contractility and VSD flow dynamics
  • Monitor for:
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Aortic root dilation (variable)

docs.title: Pulmonary Arteries
docs.text:
• Arises predominantly from morphologic right ventricle
  • Often hypoplastic, especially if subaortic stenosis develops
  • Pulmonary blood flow depends on:
  • RV-to-PA flow (not LV-to-PA, as LV has no PA outlet)
  • VSD size and restrictiveness (if small, limits pulmonary flow)
  • Degree of pulmonary stenosis if present

docs.title: DORV Classification (Surgical Perspective)
docs.text:
The surgical approach depends on VSD location relative to the great arteries and aortic position:

Type VSD Position Aorta Position Physiology Surgical Approach Subarterial VSD (Taussig-Bing) Under both PA and aorta Anterior to PA; PA more posterior Similar to TGA (cyanotic) PA switch (Rastelli-like) or arterial switch Perimembranous with anterior extension Under aorta primarily Usually anterior-left L-R shunt if no LVOTO VSD closure ± aortic repositioning; Rastelli if needed Perimembranous with posterior extension Under PA primarily Usually posterior L-R shunt; similar to VSD physiology VSD closure ± PA outflow procedures Remote VSD Far from both arteries Variable Creates challenges Complex repair; may need conduit

docs.title: Degree of Cyanosis
docs.text:
Depends on:

  1. VSD size:
  2. Small VSD → Limited LV output to RV → Cyanosis

  3. Large VSD → Better mixing → Less cyanosis

  4. Relative positions of aorta and PA:

  5. If aorta favors RV inlet → Better systemic output → Less cyanosis

  6. If aorta is "unwedged" and primarily receives RV inlet blood → Better systemic flow

  7. Associated pulmonary stenosis:

  8. Decreases pulmonary flow → Increases cyanosis

docs.title: Associated Lesions
docs.text: Lesion Frequency Significance Pulmonary stenosis 30–50% Restricts pulmonary flow; worsens cyanosis AV valve abnormalities 20–40% TV or MV dysplasia/regurgitation Heterotaxy ~30% Situs inversus, asplenia, polysplenia, IVC anomalies Left AV valve regurgitation 10–20% Volume overload if present Hypoplastic pulmonary arteries 20–30% Limits surgical options Aortic regurgitation 10–20% From VSD proximity to aortic valve CoA or aortic stenosis 5–10% Additional LVOTO

docs.title: Morphologic Assessment
docs.text:
1. Confirm both arteries from RV:
  2. Trace aorta and PA from their origins
  3. Identify RV insertion points

  4. Confirm LV does not give rise to either vessel

  5. Identify and characterize VSD:

  6. Location relative to great arteries (subarterial, perimembranous, remote)
  7. Size and restrictiveness

  8. Relationships to aortic and pulmonary valves

  9. Define great artery relationship:

  10. Anterior–posterior, side-by-side, or other

  11. Aortic position relative to pulmonary artery crucial for surgical planning

  12. Ventricular chamber size and function:

  13. RV is dominant; measure volumes and ejection fraction
  14. LV is hypoplastic; assess degree of hypoplasia

  15. Measure relative chamber sizes

  16. Coronary artery anatomy:

  17. Identify origins and course of coronary arteries
  18. Exclude anomalous coronaries (e.g., left coronary from right sinus)
  19. May require dedicated coronary CMR

docs.title: Flow Imaging
docs.text:
• 4D flow or 2D PC through great arteries:
  • Quantify aortic and pulmonary artery flows
  • Assess VSD shunt magnitude (left-to-right typically predominates)
  • Measure pulmonary stenosis gradient if present

  • Measure aortic regurgitation if suspected

  • PC through VSD (if imaging plane can capture):

  • Direction and magnitude of shunt
  • Peak velocity indicating restrictiveness

docs.title: LGE Assessment
docs.text:
• Usually minimal LGE unless associated myocarditis or fibrosis
  • Assess for scar or replacement fibrosis related to complex hemodynamics

docs.title: Neonates and Infants
docs.text:
• Cyanosis: Degree varies based on anatomy
  • Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1): Maintains ductus arteriosus to improve pulmonary blood flow if critical cyanosis
  • Balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind): May improve mixing if needed
  • Surgical intervention required in first weeks to months

docs.title: Surgical Timing and Strategy
docs.text:
Goals of repair: - Separate systemic and pulmonary circulations - Restore aorta and PA to their appropriate ventricles (if possible) - Alleviate LVOTO and pulmonary stenosis

Common approaches:

  1. Rastelli operation:
  2. For subarterial VSD or other configurations
  3. VSD closure redirects LV blood to aorta
  4. Conduit placed from RV to PA

  5. Conduit requires future replacements as child grows

  6. Arterial switch + VSD closure:

  7. For "Taussig-Bing" anatomy

  8. Rearrange great arteries + close VSD

  9. VSD closure + pulmonary artery transfer (less common):

  10. If anatomy permits

docs.title: Long-term Outcomes
docs.text:
• Rastelli with conduit: Multiple re-operations needed as child grows
  • Up to 1 in 3 patients may need heart transplantation eventually
  • LV hypoplasia may limit ability to restore normal circulation in some cases
  • Excellent immediate outcomes with good surgical technique, but long-term follow-up essential

docs.title: Cardiac
docs.text:
• Associated CHD: Very high incidence of additional anomalies
  • Heterotaxy spectrum: Up to 30% have heterotaxy, asplenia, or polysplenia
  • Coronary anomalies: 10–15% have abnormal coronary origins

docs.title: Extracardiac
docs.text:
• Heterotaxy syndrome: Howell-Jolly bodies on blood smear (asplenia); increased risk of overwhelming sepsis
  • Syndromes: Digeorge/22q11 deletion, visceral heterotaxy associations
  • Gastrointestinal: Malrotation, asplenia/polysplenia, heterotaxy

docs.title: Survival
docs.text:
• Without intervention: Inviable; affected infants die in first days to weeks
  • With surgical repair:
  • Early mortality ~5–10% (depends on complexity)
  • 10-year survival ~70–80%
  • Late mortality mainly from RV dysfunction, conduit failure, or need for transplantation

docs.title: Follow-up Essentials
docs.text:
1. Serial RV size and function assessment (echocardiography/CMR)
  2. Conduit assessment (if Rastelli): Echocardiography for stenosis and regurgitation
  3. Arrhythmia monitoring: Post-operative incision sites predispose to reentrant circuits
  4. Coronary status: Late coronary compression or ostial anomalies
  5. Antibiotic prophylaxis for endocarditis (lifelong, even after successful repair)

docs.title: Key Teaching Points
docs.text: ✓ Both great arteries from RV: Obligate VSD provides left ventricular outlet ✓ VSD anatomy determines surgical approach: Subarterial, perimembranous, or remote affects repair strategy ✓ Rastelli operation: Common strategy; requires multiple conduit replacements ✓ Heterotaxy frequent: ~30% have asplenia/polysplenia; varicella vaccination important ✓ Complex imaging: Careful segmental analysis and coronary assessment essential pre-operatively

docs.title: Anatomy
docs.text:
Hallmark: Apical displacement of the septal and posterior leaflets of the tricuspid valve from normal insertion at the annulus.

Diagnostic criterion (echo): Displacement ≥8 mm/m² (body surface area) below the mitral valve annulus level

Key structural feature: - "Atrialized" RV: Portion of RV (from TV insertion to AV junction) is thin-walled and contractually incompetent; functions as part of RA - Functional RV: Small chamber; often hypertrophic and restricted

docs.title: Physiology
docs.text:
• Tricuspid regurgitation: Almost universal
  • Leaflets are dysplastic and may not coapt properly

  • Severity varies: mild to severe

  • Right-to-left shunting: ASD or patent foramen ovale present in ~70% of cases

  • Permits R→L shunting if RA pressure is elevated → cyanosis

  • Cyanosis typically mild (SaO₂ often 90–95%)

  • Atrial arrhythmias: Accessory pathways (WPW syndrome) in ~25% of Ebstein patients

  • Risk of accessory pathway-mediated tachycardia

docs.title: Ventricular Volumes and Function
docs.text:
• Measure functional RV volume (exclude atrialized portion from RV cavity)
  • Delineate atrialization boundary by cine
  • RV EF often reduced

  • Severe dysfunction may require intervention

  • LV volume and function: Secondary effects from RV dilation (septal bulge into LV)

docs.title: Tricuspid Regurgitation
docs.text:
• Severity assessment: 4D flow quantifies regurgitant volume and fraction
  • Pathophysiology: Dysplastic TV with malcoaptation; may have prolapse of leaflet

docs.title: Associated Findings
docs.text:
• ASD/PFO: Screen for right-to-left shunt on 4D flow
  • Accessory pathway: Consider electrophysiology referral if WPW pattern on ECG
  • Other structural abnormalities: LVOTO (left ventricular outflow obstruction), pulmonary stenosis

docs.title: Atrial Enlargement
docs.text:
• RA dilation: Often marked
  • LA size: Usually normal unless secondary LA dilation from TR

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Symptomatic cyanosis: SaO₂ <90%
  • Severe RV dysfunction: RV EF <35% or significant dilation
  • Progressive arrhythmias: Refractory to medical management
  • Paradoxical embolism risk: Large PFO/ASD with cyanosis

Surgical options: - TV repair (cone procedure) or replacement - ASD closure (to reduce R→L shunt) - Arrhythmia management (if WPW)

docs.title: Medical Management
docs.text:
• Antiarrhythmics for accessory pathway-mediated arrhythmias
  • Diuretics for right heart failure
  • Anticoagulation if atrial fibrillation develops

docs.title: Imaging Follow-up
docs.text: Serial CMR to assess: - RV volume and function trajectory - TR progression - LA/RA size changes - Development of arrhythmias or symptoms requiring intervention

docs.title: Physiology
docs.text:
Goal: Eliminate the subpulmonary ventricle; direct systemic venous return directly to pulmonary arteries (passive flow).

Types: - Atriopulmonary connection: RA to PA (older, rarely used now) - Total cavopulmonary connection (TCPC): IVC and SVC → PA (standard modern approach, often with fenestration)

Staged approach: 1. Norwood procedure (if needed): Restructure aorta; RV-to-PA shunt 2. Glenn procedure (Stage 2): SVC to PA (hemi-Fontan) 3. Fontan procedure (Stage 3): IVC to PA, completing TCPC

docs.title: Critical Parameters
docs.text:
• Single (systemic) ventricle EF and EDVi: Primary prognostic marker
  • EF >40% is favorable

  • Progressive decline predicts worse outcomes

  • Fontan conduit flow: Total superior + inferior systemic venous return

  • Compare to pulmonary artery flow to assess collateral flow

  • Pulmonary artery flow distribution:

  • LPA flow
  • RPA flow

  • LPA:RPA ratio (aim for ≥0.4 for balanced distribution)

  • Pulmonary collateral flow: Calculated as (Total PA flow) − (Fontan conduit flow)

  • Normal: <20% of systemic cardiac output

  • Significant collaterals (>20%): Bypass pulmonary vascular bed, reduce PA flow

  • Systemic venous collaterals: Bypasses Fontan circuit

  • Porto-systemic collaterals (suggest elevated IVC pressure)
  • Scan to include abdomen/inguinal region

docs.title: AV Valve Function
docs.text:
• Atrioventricular valve regurgitation: Common and progressive
  • Quantify regurgitant fraction by 4D flow
  • Severe regurgitation increases risk of failure

docs.title: Additional Assessments
docs.text:
• Ventricular function and fibrosis: LGE helps identify early remodeling
  • Pulmonary vascular resistance markers: Elevated Fontan pressure correlates with elevated collateral flow
  • IVC flow pattern: Retrograde flow suggests elevated IVC pressure (poor prognosis marker)

docs.title: Fenestration
docs.text: Intentional R→L shunt: Small connection between Fontan conduit and RA (or fenestration in baffle). - Allows decompression of elevated venous pressure - Trade-off: Mild cyanosis (lower SaO₂, typically 92–95%) - CMR findings: Expect Qp:Qs <1.0; visible shunt on 4D flow

docs.title: Long-term Complications
docs.text:
• Protein-losing enteropathy (PLE): Albumin loss from intestinal lymphatic obstruction
  • Risk factors: Low EF, elevated Fontan pressure, severe collaterals
  • Atrial arrhythmias: Intra-atrial reentrant tachycardia (IART) common
  • Thromboembolic risk: Consider anticoagulation if persistent atrial fibrillation
  • Progressive ventricular dysfunction: EF decline over years to decades
  • Hepatic cirrhosis: Chronic venous congestion → fibrosis

docs.title: Imaging Follow-up
docs.text: Serial CMR (typically yearly in young children, varies by stability) to track: - Ventricular volume and function - Growth of collateral vessels - Progression of valve disease - Signs of protein-losing enteropathy

docs.title: D-TGA: Post-Arterial Switch (Jatene Procedure)
docs.text: Physiology: Aorta arises from right ventricle, pulmonary artery from left ventricle. Arterial switch repositions great vessels to anatomically correct positions.

docs.title: Post-repair Assessment
docs.text:
Neo-aortic root dilation: The native pulmonary artery (now functioning as aorta) commonly dilates. - Measure at annulus, sinuses of Valsalva, sinotubular junction - Progressive dilation may warrant intervention

Neo-pulmonary stenosis (RVOTO): - Right ventricle now pumps to pulmonary artery (behind aorta) - Narrowing can develop at anastomotic site - Assess by PC velocity; use Bernoulli equation

Coronary anatomy: - Native coronaries are re-implanted into neoaortic root - Assess for ostial stenosis (best by coronary CT or invasive catheterization)

Ventricular function: - LV is now systemic ventricle (normal location) - May show functional decline if post-ischemic complications

docs.title: D-TGA: Post-Atrial Switch (Mustard/Senning Procedure)
docs.text:
Note: This is older operative approach; fewer cases in modern practice but important for long-term follow-up

Physiology: Intra-atrial baffle redirects inferior/superior vena cava to mitral valve and pulmonary veins to tricuspid valve. Systemic RV: RV remains systemic ventricle; bears pressure load chronically.

docs.title: Long-term Assessment (CMR focus)
docs.text:
Systemic RV volume and function: - RV EF and EDV critical prognostic markers - EF <40% indicates significant dysfunction - Progressive EF decline predicts worse long-term outcomes

Baffle complications: - SVC baffle stenosis (obstruction of superior vena cava pathway) - IVC baffle stenosis (obstruction of inferior vena cava pathway) - Baffle leak: R→L shunting allows deoxygenated blood to systemic circulation

AV valve regurgitation: - Systemic (tricuspid) regurgitation from chronic RV dilation

Arrhythmias: High incidence of atrial fibrillation and flutter due to stretched atria

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text: Long-term follow-up includes echocardiography and periodic CMR to assess RV decline and baffle integrity.

docs.title: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
docs.text: Four components: VSD + overriding aorta + RVOTO + RVH

docs.title: Pre-repair
docs.text: Early diagnosis via fetal echo or postnatal echocardiography. Surgical candidates typically have adequate pulmonary arteries and left-to-right shunting with cyanosis.

docs.title: CMR Evaluation
docs.text: Measurement Normal Concern RV EDVi 80–110 mL/m² >160 suggests progressive dilation RV EF >45% <40% = significant dysfunction Pulmonary RF <20% >40% = severe PR LV EF >55% QRS duration <160 ms >180 ms = arrhythmia risk

docs.title: Key Findings
docs.text:
• Pulmonary regurgitation: Measure PR by 4D flow at main PA. Progressive PR leads to RV dilation; major reason for pulmonary valve replacement (PVR)
  • Residual RVOTO: Measure by PC velocity at site of narrowing (often infundibular). Use Bernoulli equation
  • RPA stenosis: Common post-repair. Compare LPA:RPA flow ratios
  • Aortic root dilation: Common sequelae. Measure at annulus, sinuses of Valsalva, sinotubular junction, ascending aorta

docs.title: PVR Timing
docs.text: CMR RV volumes guide PVR indication. Most centers use: - RVEDVi >150–160 mL/m² AND/OR RF >40% as thresholds for consideration of intervention

docs.title: Complications
docs.text:
• Arrhythmias (sustained VT risk if QRS >180 ms)
  • Aortic root aneurysm
  • Left ventricular dysfunction (late finding)
  • Sudden cardiac death risk in untreated severe RV dilation

docs.title: Classification
docs.text: Type Prevalence Location Features Perimembranous 80% Membranous septum Most common; can extend into inlet or outlet Muscular 5–20% Muscular septum May close spontaneously; varies by location Outlet (Supracristal) 5–8% Above pulmonary and aortic valves Risk of aortic regurgitation Inlet (Endocardial cushion) 8–10% Below AV valves Part of AVSD spectrum

docs.title: Hemodynamic Significance
docs.text:
Shunt magnitude from CMR 4D Flow:

Qp:Qs Category Clinical Significance <1.5 Small Hemodynamically insignificant; unlikely to need closure 1.5–2.0 Moderate May warrant monitoring; closure considered if progressive >2.0 Large Significant L→R shunt; closure indicated

docs.title: Special Considerations
docs.text:
Eisenmenger Syndrome: - Reversed shunt (Qp:Qs <1.0) and cyanosis from fixed pulmonary hypertension - Irreversible; closure contraindicated (would cause systemic RV afterload crisis) - Managed medically with pulmonary vasodilators

Aortic regurgitation: - Particularly with outlet/supracristal defects - Assess severity on cine imaging and by 4D flow

Associated lesions: - Concomitant ASD in primum type - Pulmonary stenosis (cyanotic form)

docs.title: CMR Assessment
docs.text:
• Defect location and size: Dark blood imaging (HASTE/TSE) axial stack
  • Flow calculation: 4D flow at pulmonary artery and aorta for Qp:Qs
  • Ventricular function: SAX cine stack of each ventricle
  • LV dilation: Secondary to volume overload from L→R shunt

docs.title: Closure Indications
docs.text:
• Qp:Qs ≥1.5 (Class IIa)
  • Qp:Qs >2.0 in children (Class I)
  • Pulmonary hypertension without reversal (Class I)
  • Absolute contraindication: Eisenmenger physiology

docs.text:
The mitral annulus is saddle-shaped and D-shaped — always measure in systole.

docs.title: Neo-LVOT Assessment
docs.text:
Neo-LVOT Obstruction

Critical pre-procedure measurement. Critical threshold: neo-LVOT area <170–190 mm² is high risk for obstruction. Model by reformatting CT with virtual device in place; assess the triangle between device, AMVL, and IVS.

docs.text:

docs.title: Thrombus Protocol
docs.text:
Delayed Phase (60 s)

Residual enhancement on delayed phase effectively excludes thrombus. Absence of fill in on delayed = LAA thrombus → do NOT proceed to closure until resolved.
